awd_titl_txt: Is Static Soil Density a Viable Assumption for Studying Surface Hydrologic Processes?
awd_abstract_narration:
A soil surface is an interface between the ground and the atmosphere.  Soil surface layer conditions influence the Earth's hydrologic cycle by impacting rainfall infiltration and runoff, soil water evaporation, and storage of plant available water. Properties of soil surface layers are dynamic in time.  Tillage loosens soil surface layers, while vehicular traffic and raindrop impacts cause soil surface layers to compact.  The dynamic density and porosity natures of soil surface layers are not well known.  Furthermore, the dynamic hydraulic properties of soil surface layers are almost unknown.  This study is designed to measure dynamic soil surface layer properties under a range of field conditions and to evaluate the impacts of these properties on the hydrologic cycle.  Advancing knowledge of these processes is critical for understanding important land surface-atmosphere exchanges (e.g. permafrost release of greenhouse gases and evapotranspiration) and could lead to better agricultural water management. 

The proposed study will use newly developed thermo-TDR sensors to provide co-located, in situ measurements of surface soil water content and thermal properties.  Thermo-TDR sensors are also able to measure dynamic surface soil density and porosity. Proposed field and numerical experiments will address three fundamental questions: i. Over what temporal scales and to what extent does loosened soil density change? ii. Can patterns be identified to facilitate development of predictive relationships, incorporating transient density, with other fundamental soil hydraulic and thermal properties? iii. How does shifting soil density directly impact water and energy exchange at the land surface-atmosphere interface and mass and heat transfer in subsurface soil? Addressing these questions provides opportunity to transform the hydrologic sciences, strengthen analytical frameworks and improve predictive theory. Proposed work, guided by specific expertise on soil properties and processes, and supported with newly developed tools, provides the opportunity to measure dynamic soil surface layer properties under a range of field conditions. Because knowledge of soil density and porosity is fundamental to investigation of soil hydraulic, thermal, and gas transfer properties and processes, new discoveries achieved in this study offer transformative potential for wide ranging investigations of land surface, hydrologic cycle, and ecosystem dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Research was aimed at determining the impacts of shifting soil bulk density directly on soil thermal and hydraulic properties, which dictate terrestrial water availability, land-atmosphere energy exchange, and soil temperature. We re-designed the novel thermo-TDR soil sensor and used it to perform field experiments in Iowa and North Carolina to measure bulk density increases with time following soil tillage. The thermo-TDR sensor enabled us to determine in situ bulk density, water content, thermal and hydraulic properties, and temperature. We also tested a commercially available combination of sensors to determine simultaneously soil water content and soil bulk density. All of the field measurements confirmed that bulk density was dynamic with time, and soil thermal and hydraulic properties changed as bulk density changed.  The measurements also served as inputs to a computer model used to evaluate how dynamic bulk density affected soil water content and soil temperature for a variety of soils and weather conditions.

The largest changes in soil bulk density occurred within the first few weeks after tillage, which reduced the thickness of the tilled layer by 25%. Increases in bulk density strongly affected water retention: in low bulk density soil just following tillage, rainwater was only stored in about one third of the pore volume, while after the bulk density increased, decreased pore volume along with increased water retention resulted in rainwater being retained in two thirds of the pore volume. Saturated hydraulic conductivity decreased by an order of magnitude as bulk density increased following tillage.

Models were used to evaluate volumetric heat capacity, thermal conductivity, soil thermal diffusivity, water retention, hydraulic conductivity, and vapor diffusivity, over a range of bulk density values. A 10% change in bulk density led to a 10% change in thermal conductivity, 10% change in saturated and residual water content, 50% change in saturated hydraulic conductivity, and 80% change in vapor diffusivity. Three field seasons were simulated with a computer model for a range of bulk density values. When bulk density increased from 1.2 to 1.5 Mg m-3, soil temperature variation decreased by 2.1?C in shallow layers and increased by 1?C in subsurface layers. Surface water content differed by 0.02 m3 m-3 for various bulk density values during drying events. Surface energy balance components varied as bulk density increased. Latent heat flux decreased by 6%, sensible heat flux increased by 9%, and magnitude of ground heat flux varied by 18%. Because transient bulk density impacts surface conditions and fluxes, it clearly warrants consideration in future field and modeling investigations.

A key discovery from this research project was that a combination of commercially available sensors could accurately measure in situ water content and bulk density. The commercial sensor estimates of bulk density agreed well with independent gravimetrically-derived bulk density values, with average root mean square error of 0.12 Mg m-3. Because commercial multi-sensor combinations provide accurate bulk density estimates, interested scientists can readily include dynamic bulk density measurements in their field studies.

Outcomes from this project are a newly re-designed thermo-TDR sensor and a suggested combination of commercial sensors for improved measurements of dynamic soil bulk density, and its impact on surface energy and water balances, soil thermal and hydraulic properties, and on soil water content and temperature. Sensor measurements can be applied to improve agricultural water use efficiency, assess crop water availability, and manage soil temperature. The project also led to development of several soil property models that can be applied to predict the effects of changing bulk density on water retention, hydraulic conductivity, and thermal properties. The project results have a potential to impact water availability for human use.  Knowing more about soil surface water balance can lead to improved water use and water availability strategies. These new measurements will aid the micro-meteorological community on improving energy balance measurement techniques. These measurements and models will also help climate modelers to improve their algorithms for partitioning near surface energy and water balance components.  The results will be used by the scientific community for the development of enhanced hydrology and climate models.

This research project also offered important opportunities for engagement with the scientific community and for training of new scientists, including 2 post-doc researchers, 1 Ph.D. student, and 2 M.S. students. One of the M.S. students is an African American minority student. A workshop on the construction and use of thermo-TDR sensors to measure soil properties was attended by thirty-three graduate students and early-career researchers from the USA, China, Canada, Germany, and Japan. Research results were published in national and international journals and disseminated at national and international conferences in the U.S.A. and in Asia.
